column1: #Text=The torque trace in FIG. 13 is split up into three distinct regions: A, B and C.
#Text=The average torque in each of these regions is given by a, b and c, which are calculated as follows: 13a = 1 T A t 0 t 1 d t b = 1 T B t 1 t 2 d t c = 1 T C t 2 t 3 d t
#Text=[0106] The acceleration torque is then given by: 14 d_accl = b - ( c + a ) 2
#Text=[0107] FIG. 13 shows the torque trace with the ripple component removed.
#Text=This method is applicable with torque ripple present, provided that each region contains an integer number of ripple cycles.
#Text=The periods T.sub.A, T.sub.B and T.sub.C must therefore be chosen carefully to ensure this is the case.
#Text=However, the greater the number of ripple cycles in each region there are, the less critical it is to have an integer number of cycles.
#Text=[0108] The processor implementation for an exemplary embodiment is detailed below.

#Text=Discretising the integration process yields the following equations for a, b and c: 15a =T s T A n = 1( t 1 - t 0 ) / T s d ( n ) b =T s T B n = 1( t 2 - t 1 ) / T s d ( n ) c =T s T C n = 1( t 3 - t 2 ) / T s d ( n )

#Text=[0109] The acceleration torque is therefore given by: 16 d_accl = T s(1 T B n = 1( t 2 - t 1 ) / T s d ( n ) - 1 2 T A n = 1( t 1 - t 0 ) / T s d ( n ) - 1 2 T C n = 1( t 3 -t 2 ) / T s d ( n ) )
